@Pyriphlegethon  I've searched these codes in World Bank Health http://data.worldbank.org/topic/health.
I've found COD for Congo (as is already implemented).
I've found KSV for Kosovo that is KOS in Caravel.
I've not found  in World Bank Health ADO, ZAR, WBG, ROM, IMY, TMP.
I've found CHI for "Channel Islands" that is for "Chile" in Caravel in "cioc" key.

Searching for a solution I've found that World Bank seems to use this standard https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-3 but in their datas returns non standard keys.
Nevermind. I figured i out, using postagg
https://github.com/airbnb/caravel/issues/1098

Very interesting idea, how will that work with 'group by', 'metrics' parameters in various viz types?
The "query parameters" would be completely independent of the typical "group by" and "metrics" fields.
a couple comments, otherwise lgtm

Since almost every type of visualization requires 'groupby' and 'metrics'
parameters, how could we visualize those query-based slices without them?

i think we could improve the organization of our components, but that can be in a subsequent PR.
i like they way the redux docs use the pattern of container and presentational components: http://redux.js.org/docs/basics/UsageWithReact.html#implementing-components

https://github.com/dpgaspar/Flask-AppBuilder/issues/318

While debugging I was able to get:

```
from flask import session
print(session['page_history'])
[u'http://localhost:8081/tablemodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/dashboardmodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/slicemodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/tablemodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/dashboardmodelview/edit/99']
session['page_history']
```

FAB uses prev url for the redirect:
https://github.com/dpgaspar/Flask-AppBuilder/blob/af095ac4094d068fa2dd467bd01fa8b95d697fc1/flask_appbuilder/baseviews.py#L193

Once the history didn't have any `http://localhost:8081/dashboardmodelview/edit/XX`

```
[u'http://localhost:8081/tablemodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/dashboardmodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/slicemodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/tablemodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/dashboardmodelview/list/']
```

Hmm, this is a new build failure after I clicked "update branch".  The previous CI build did succeed.  I'm not sure if this was from complications from merging 4164d6c or if this is a problem in master brought into this PR by updating the branch.

Looks like session history works across tabs:

```
[u'http://localhost:8081/slicemodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/dashboardmodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/dashboardmodelview/edit/99', u'http://localhost:8081/slicemodelview/list/', u'http://localhost:8081/slicemodelview/edit/119']
```

I opened the `dashboardmodelview/list` and then `dashboardmodelview/edit/XX` on one tab and then opened  `slicemodelview/list` and `slicemodelview/edit/XX` on another and moved back to the tab with `dashboardmodelview/edit`.
Saving the `dashboardmodelview/edit`. redirects to the `slicemodelview/list`
that looks like transient error

I'm using gunicorn and explicitly sending the log output to stdout.

```
gunicorn \
  --error-logfile - \
  --access-logfile - \
  -w 8 \
  -k gevent \
  -b 0.0.0.0:8080 \
  --timeout 120 \
  --limit-request-line 0 \
  --limit-request-field_size 0 \
  --forwarded-allow-ips="*" \
  caravel:app
```

it's harder to catch legit JS errors when there are so many warnings in the console. these are mostly propType errors and easy to fix.

+1 I would also like to add my voice to this issue. I've created a 2 minute screencast to demonstrate what's happening here: https://youtu.be/J3xZLPb4L7M

I honestly don't know how to get around it (it's a blocker, not merely an inconvenience) -- even after changing the Country code to be the correct one, I can't get it to re-query.

@jbwhit now i am curious: if it's a blocker for you why don't you invest your time or money to fix it?

The issue here (surprise!) is that long running queries suck: would it matter to kill queries if the query takes 5 seconds? Sometimes the fix for this slowness is easy as adding indexes but you have to profile and see where the time is spent.
